ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This is really a fun class and QFT is just beautiful. Even though students may not use QFT for their research, not taking class implies that you will graduate with missing some fun parts of physics.
I would recommend this course to another student- if taught by Tom.
This is the first course in quantum field theory which introduces the basic ideas of the subject. It is something every student working in the particle physics should take. Also, every theorist.
I would recommend this to anyone studying theoretical or experimental particle theory because it gives a good foundation to understanding the problems studied in this field.
Yes, Prof. Appelquist was a pleasure to listen to.
This course was largely a derivation of QFT. Every student should take it in order to understand where the formalism comes from.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Not a physicist unless you've suffered QFT.
I don't have an answer for this question, I just enjoyed this class so much!
This class is certainly relevant to a student who wants to do particle physics. I'm sure the information I learned in this course will be useful when writing the theory portion of my thesis.
This is the first course in the quantum field theory so it is more or less required for anyone who wants to do physics.
It was important to know for my research.
An understanding of quantum field theory will be essential for my research.
